Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Mountains and Minds: A Program in Chemical Biology
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award from the Division of Chemistry (CHE) and the Division of Biological Infrastructure (DBI) at the National Science Foundation supports a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site led by Professor Mary J. Cloninger at Montana State University (MSU) and Professor Ruben M. Ceballos at the University of Montana. Undergraduate research will occur primarily in the following areas of chemical biology: activity based protein profiling, radical reactions in biology, antimicrobial materials, cardiac mitochondrial functions, protein-small molecule interactions, protein structure-function relationships, enzymology, metabolomics, bioinspired nanoreactors, neurotransmitter receptor, biofuel production, and membrane biology. These areas are all the focus of current research in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at Montana State University, in the Native American Research Lab at the University of Montana, and at Chiang Mai University in Thailand. Most participants will conduct ten weeks of research in Montana and will attend weekly workshops and group meetings to learn about state of the art instrumentation and methods for chemical biology. These students, especially the Native American students, will have the option of working the entire summer at MSU or in the Native American Research Lab at the University of Montana, or distributing their time between both locations. In addition, two Native American students who already have research experience will spend four weeks in Montana and six weeks in Thailand. All students will participate in a daylong symposium, will write a final paper, and will present a poster about their research.

The REU Site is committed to working with Native American students, students from regional tribal colleges, and students from small Montana and regional colleges with limited resources. The partnership of Montana State University, the Native American Research Lab at the University of Montana, and Chiang Mai University in Thailand will allow research in chemical biology to be more accessible to all students, including Native American students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This REU program supported twenty-nine students to perform summer undergraduate research in chemical biology. Twenty-three students spent their summers at Montana State University, and six Native American students performed summer research in Malaysia each summer.

Intellectual Merit REU projects were designed to use chemical approaches to study biological questions including activity based protein profiling, radical reactions in biology, antimicrobial materials, cardiac mitochondrial functions, protein-small molecule interactions, protein structure-function relationships, enzymology, metabolomics, bioinspired nanoreactors, neurotransmitter receptor, biofuel production, and membrane biology. These areas are all the focus of current, cutting-edge research in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at Montana State University, in the Native American Research Lab, and at Universiti Teknologi MARA in Malaysia. Advancement of research at the chemistry/biology interface is an intellectual merit of the proposal. Five peer reviewed manuscripts with REU co-authors were published during the three year project period, and a sixth publication has been submitted.

An important part of the research experience in our REU program is the involvement of the participants in research teams composed of a faculty mentor, a graduate student assistant, and the REU fellow (and, in Malaysia, with a peer mentor). The principal advantages of this organizational structure are: (1) it ensures close faculty-undergraduate relationships, (2) there are greater and more diverse opportunities for mentoring and instruction, (3) undergraduates gain a student perspective on pursuing an advanced, research-based degree. A major goal of our program is to bring the undergraduate from an initial position as the junior member of the research group to a position of scientific expertise by the end of the summer. We emphasize that, although their faculty advisors tailor the projects for them, undergraduates are involved in forefront research such that, under good circumstances, the results are publishable in a major journal.  Providing Native American students with a faculty mentor who is an American Indian and with a peer group of student researchers who are Native Americans is a critical component of this REU.

Broader Impacts We are committed to working with Native American students, students from regional Tribal Colleges, and students from small Montana and regional colleges with limited resources. The objective of our REU program is to introduce these students to state of the art instrumentation and frontier research techniques for chemical biology. In addition to the research programs on-site at Montana State University, two Native American students performed research in Malaysia each summer. The broader impacts of supporting research opportunities for Native Americans students, a demographic where only 13% of adults have college degrees, are clearly enormous. This REU program allows interdisciplinary research, which uses chemical approaches to address biological problems, to be more accessible to all students including Native Americans students.
